title: Relative Clauses - Which, That or What 3
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2 or B1whatB2.

sentence: You should always tell the boss
remarks: Corr: what. The verb 'tell' has two objects, one is 'the boss' the other is the clause starting with 'what'. So there's no noun to refer back to.
Corr: what. This is a question, but if we look at the normal word order (This is what you can...), we can see that 'what' comes after the verb 'be', so there's no noun to refer back to.

Corr: which or that. Here we refer back to a noun 'all', so we cannot use 'what'. The relative pronoun 'that' would be better here than 'which' because if the clause contains 'all', we prefer to use 'that' instead of 'which'.

sentence: I haven't read the book on
remarks: Corr: which. Here we refer back to a noun 'the book', so only 'which' is correct. The relative pronoun 'that' is not correct here because we cannot use it after prepositions.

sentence: My son doesn't understand that he cannot always get
remarks: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, 'what' comes immediately after a verb (get).

sentence: Do you still remember the look
remarks: Corr: which or that. Here we refer back to a noun 'the look', so we cannot use 'what'.

sentence: my parents wanted me to do.
remarks: Corr: what. Here 'what' comes immediately after a verb (did), so there's no noun to refer back to.

sentence: are indeed very important to all of us.
remarks: Corr: which or that. Here we refer back to a noun 'topics', so we cannot use 'what'.
Corr: what. Here 'what' comes after a verb (pay for), so there's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.

sentence: Bob and Ed talked about things about
I have never heard. They're so clever.
remarks: Corr: which. Here we refer back to a noun 'things', so only 'which' is correct. The relative pronoun 'that' is not correct here because we cannot use it after prepositions.
